items.content_text: Context: This article is a full version of the original article, which you can find here. This version is updated, the other is the original commit. Choose wisely.üßô‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏èMy personal website is pretty much targeted for me - so I can publish as much as possible.The fact that it‚Äôs live online, adds some pressure on the quality of what I publish, but more importantly helps me overcome my perfectionistic tendencies. For context, it took me 3 months to write this article. It was worth it, but I could have done it in 2 weeks. I just kept getting stuck in perfecting, even if deep down I knew that it will never be perfect anyway, and that‚Äôs totally fine, too. In the end, the 2.5 months of extra time increased its final quality by 1%.SAD TROMBONE PLAYSWell‚Ä¶ Mistakes were made, and it seems that I learned something from them:WEBSITE ENTERSHere‚Äôs how it works:I publish unfinished stuff, but I publish it consistently. And since everything is written and managed directly inside my Obsidian vault, which is the central point of my digital focus, I can update anything I publish effortlessly, at any time, on my laptop or phone. I press Alt+Tab, write a letter ‚Äúg‚Äù (for GitHub Desktop to appear as the first result) and press enter. Then click ‚Äúcommit to main‚Äù and finalise the process by clicking ‚Äúpush origin‚Äù. Robots do their work, and the website is updated.It takes me approximately 2 seconds.I keep seeing all my files on the left. Folder structure includes (among other things) three web projects (my personal website, journalsmarter and microsolidarity in pico), each with /assets folder containing images. I can manipulate all files, restructure websites, move files from one project to another, link in between etc, and then in 2 seconds all changes are published.This is the first part of my strategy, which is complimented by the fact that not many people read my personal website (or at least I assume so, and I have no data to check, because the site has no tracking of any sort, which is a deliberate decision because I find tracking on the internet quite creepy. But I digress). Not many readers = not much pressure, in fact it‚Äôs probably just me and you right now who have ever visited this page.No resistance to publish + no pressure to publish is a combo that really does it for me.Here‚Äôs my current example:I was editing a poem which I wrote during a sailing trip which begun the transition into the chapter of my life that has just concluded as I write these words right now (okay, not exactly, but the actual day of the new beginning is only a couple of days off, which makes me smile feeling into the magical world of synchronicities).As I was editing the poem, an idea bounced into my mind: to start writing a meta article about my writing workflow, because it feels like a useful gift I could offer to someone who‚Äôd like to make writing a self-inflicted addiction.That‚Äôs kinda what happened to me.I struggled to build a digital publishing habit, so I turned it into addiction.( I can feel my certified habit coach part giving me a shoulder pat as I type these words, btw. )I clicked Ctrl+N, abandoned the poem for a while (we‚Äôll come back to it later), and begun writing a new note with a raw title How I Use My Personal Website.I furiously typed the next 598 words. Breath. 600.Then took this screenshot:(There will be a few more in this article - I‚Äôve been taking them occasionally since I want to show how I do it, instead of just telling the story.)If I‚Äôd like to publish it right now, I‚Äôd rename the name of the note by clicking on it - so it can be formatted for publishing. I‚Äôd call it:2022-04-18-personal-website-flowWhich would make me consider the title of this article. In the past I‚Äôd obsess about finding a perfect title, but now I‚Äôd just leave it as it is, noticing my recovering perfectionist part closing its eyes with horror!üôàThe part would get absolutely terrified, as it would begin following the note with this article being moved into the folder containing my published website./web/heymichal.github.io/_postsAt this point I actually went through the steps I just outlined, which brought the third look at the title of this article, which resulted in a decision to call it:Personal Website Flow - How I Use This WebsiteNot perfect, but good enough for now and safe enough to try.I‚Äôve copy-pasted the front matter from another post (I could have inserted it from template to make it faster), which forced me to add a description and relevant tags.And just like that this note is ready to publish.21üöÄIt‚Äôs live.Please note that it‚Äôs imperfect as fuck.I mean there is a paragraph typed below that I wrote before and decided not to include, but felt bad to delete it because it feels like a good paragraph to come back to at some point. Moreover, there are no screenshots included, and the links are all missing.Definitely suboptimal.But here‚Äôs the most important thing:I just published a 911 words article in 20 minutes or so. That‚Äôs a second thing I published today.Hey, I might tweet it, just for the laughs. I feel like it‚Äôs something that Rob would appreciate.As I get ready to copy the link so I can place it into the tweet, I start reading the published article. Perfect - I‚Äôll catch some basic spelling mistakes and small shit like that. I won‚Äôt bother with deep proof reading, images or links.‚è≥Proofreading is now complete, which means I can cmd+Tab to GitHub Desktop and commit.That is all, folks.Funny enough, I decide not to take this final step right now, because I notice that lonely paragraph again, and on an impulse decide to make it an integral part of this article, rather than leaving a few random lines at the end of the article completely out of context. I guess that‚Äôs fair to you..To give context, we need to return to the poem.I was editing it so I can get it ready for a spoken word collaboration with Jo√£o Moreira - one of the two Portuguese men whom I connected with deeply many years back in Albania, and on my return to Edinburgh which was my home at the time, I immediately booked my tickets to Portugal to fly there 2 months later. It turned out that I‚Äôd find a Person I would spend 8 years together with, and eventually move to Portugal, where I‚Äôm living now (although it‚Äôs not the continental part of Portugal).Okay, tangent finished. It‚Äôs still random. Forgive me.In any case, the poem is still awaiting editing, which is actually perfect, because I feel like my work here is done for now.I just need two clicks to republish this article, send the link to Rob, and then come back to what I was doing, before a sudden breeze of air would bring me here together with you.BIRDS SURFING OCEAN WIND VIDEO(video in tweet)I used to be a turtle.Now I am a bird.üê¶ps. Next time we meet in person, feel free to ask me to greet you with the wonderfully strange bird call from the island located not too far from the Atlantis. I have a feeling you will love it.tweet proof.(Funny: the obsidian I tagged in that tweet is the wrong one üòÇ )

Earlier today, a friend reached out asking to cancel our learning pod meeting. It seems that calls and other stuff took over her day, and she forgot to keep some free time to eat.

I replied immediately:

For context, I‚Äôm the guy who loves free space in calendars, async work and time away from digital devices. Considering that my last few weeks are basically non-stop action from morning to late at night, it seems like now is a good moment to pause and ask myself gently:

WTF ARE YOU DOING, MICHA≈Å?

Checking in to my Enspiral Work Pod was a perfect opportunity to reflect on that question. Here‚Äôs what came up:

I know very well that this is not sustainable modus operandi and I know that in the next week I will make an effort to increase the amount of free space in my day. On the other hand, I‚Äôve noticed that in order to keep up with all the open projects I‚Äôm fuelling my energy into at the moment, I needed to step up my personal productivity game, and drop some projects that I just couldn‚Äôt keep up with anymore.

In other words, the times of nakurw {roughly translated as ‚Äúfull fucking thrust‚Äù} forced me to cut the crap and develop a super effective way of juggling all my things to do without even noticing.

After all I am a juggler.

ü§π‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è

Let‚Äôs geek out on this for a bit, shall we?

1. Braindump into Obsidian

When in doubt - Braindump ‚úÖ

Obsidian is the central point of my digital focus. I write everything there and continuously optimise it for effortlessness.

So: I created a note called Braindump ‚úÖ and started dumping all the shit I want to do there.

It‚Äôs kinda like a backlog, but I don‚Äôt need another app for it.

I progressively edit the list every time I look at it, which is kinda all the time, and rearrange the order of items in order of priority. Whenever I notice resistance suggesting that a task is too big to execute, or not clear enough, I replace it with a smaller version of that task, or define it better.

I also added some basic guidance on top:

In this example ‚Äútax return‚Äù is way too big, and I replaced with a single step from my accounting checklist.

Whenever I complete a task, I move it to the done ‚úÖ section below all the tasks and feel the boost of endorfins kicking in.

2. Timebox in Proton Calendar

I timebox almost everything into my calendar, including meetings and work slots.

For work slots, I write specific tasks I intend on executing.

During the day I just follow the plan and dynamically adjust calendar events as needed. Whenever a task is done, I mark it as ‚úÖ.

3. Reply Immediately

I use the octopus of my digital communication channels (Signal, Telegram, Whatsapp, Email, Slack, Discord‚Ä¶) to dynamically brainstorm, schedule, and move tasks forward.

When working with others, I aim to reply as soon as possible in order to leave the ball at their side. This way I don‚Äôt need to remember to do something - it eventually comes back to me whenever the other person is ready to bounce it back. Most people take their sweet time to reply, which is perfect because it gives me time for other tasks.

Of course, this is not a perfect system and I‚Äôm not perfect either, duh.

Sometimes I take much longer to reply, or forget to follow up on something. In any case, it works most of the times, and if a task is mission critical, it is recorded somewhere else, so I won‚Äôt forget about it completely. Worst case scenario it will take me longer to get around to it.

OK Computer, that‚Äôs it for the digital stuff.

üíª

Let‚Äôs zoom out for a bit into the good, old organic world.

(twitter thread about my digital and analogue workspace.)

4. Journal-it-All

My journal is my swiss-army-knife and One Ring to Rule Them All.

I journal everyday with Infinity Squares, as well as record tons of information, brainstorm, process, meditate and so on. Journaling is the key practice in my life, and the longest habit I kept consistently -> I haven‚Äôt skipped a day since 2017, or something like that.

While I prefer my digital tools for day-to-day tasks and calendar management, pen and paper is king for brainstorming and continuously re-aligning with my Big Dreams.

Here‚Äôs an example of my Moonly Page with the Squares, intentions, and important notes-to-self, which I want to see every day.

And here‚Äôs brainstorming / structuring a workshop to boost an Enspiral friend on her new business venture:

5. Whiteboard

I have a whiteboard. I love whiteboards. I use it mostly to incubate ideas over a period of a few days. I write/draw stuff whenever I feel like, until incubation process is completed and I can turn an idea into reality.

Here‚Äôs a half-incubated participatory experience called Merging:

That‚Äôs it, folks.

Simple, fast, efficient.

Wish me luck.

Context: I wrote this text while at sea (original scan at the end), a couple of days after departing from Edinburgh, which used to be my Home for seven years, and it still does feel like my hometown somehow.

Back then, I sailed into a new chapter of my life, which funny enough is now about to end with another Sailing Career Development adventure taking me to whatever awaits next.

I‚Äôm in the process of recording this text as a spoken-word-music collaboration with Jo√£o Moreira aka Instil. For now the pre-premiere version is available for my Patrons.

‚õµÔ∏è

Time is gone
and along with the sea
my heart is beating
setting the tone
for discovery

I‚Äôm floating and believing
That what I still can‚Äôt see
Is right there
in front of me
waiting patiently
until I‚Äôm ready
to notice.

I‚Äôm gone
and I‚Äôm here
the same,
but always different.
and it‚Äôs hard to put this feeling into words,
so I convince myself that
perhaps there is no point
in doing so.
And I float

on words words words
that matter not
sailing my desires
towards true north
fully aligned
with this present moment

What a bliss!

And I am grateful for every breath and sound
every passing wave we found
gently caressing the hull
of this sweet abyss.

The Sun is about to kiss
the horizon, bringing yet another night
at sea

My soul is singing peacefully
with sweet melodies
of tranquility
I now found

There is so much space around!
So much to fill with joy
and birds are calling us down

There is so much to witness!

There is so much life around!
And our little boat is an integral part
of the infinite vastness of truth,
moving through the waves that found
us,
as we cross gently
Towards the open horizon
Towards the setting Sun
Towards an undefined place
at the right pace

A pace that feels right.

We‚Äôre moving slowly
Deliberately
Taking time to breathe
and sing with courage
In tune with the world
we‚Äôre a part of.

As fast as the wind permits.
As fast as our dreams.

We grow

We grow and let go and move on
To finally feel at ease
At home.

And who knows‚Ä¶
Maybe one day I‚Äôll find you on a journey towards a distant shore?
Being mesmerised
for a few moments more
together
in awe
with the everpresent water
carrying us away
Wherever we would like to go
provided that the Ocean will be kind
to our Souls
and our fragile bodies

There is no need to fear this magnificent old being.
Fear kills
by clouding hearts
with dread

Instead,
Let‚Äôs Be Courage, Love and Respect,
being grateful for every breath
and every mile behind us
and in front of us
And again
Let‚Äôs sing together with the roaring wind
and dance on every passing wave
celebrating being alive
and awake
right now
right Here

we are present
pure and vulnerable,
Facing our true essence:

Being weak,
and strong enough to admit it.

adrift with purpose
and committed
to the heartbeat of the Earth
dreaming awake
tuned and reflected
in patterns
of the waves

illuminated

and

connected

As I was editing the poem, an idea bounced into my mind: to start writing a meta article about my writing workflow, because it feels like a useful gift I could offer to someone who‚Äôd like to make writing a self-inflicted addiction.

That‚Äôs kinda what happened to me.

I struggled to build a digital publishing habit, so I turned it into addiction.

( I can feel my [certified habit coach part] giving me a shoulder pat as I type these words, btw. )

I clicked Ctrl+N, abandoned the poem for a while (we‚Äôll come back to it later), and begun writing a new note with a raw title How I Use My Personal Website.

I furiously typed the next 598 words. Breath. 600.

Then took this screenshot:

IMG

(There will be a few more in this article - I‚Äôve been taking them occasionally since I want to show how I do it, instead of just telling the story.)

If I‚Äôd like to publish it right now, I‚Äôd rename the name of the note by clicking on it - so it can be formatted for publishing. I‚Äôd call it:

2022-04-18-personal-website-flow

Which would make me consider the title of this article. In the past I‚Äôd obsess about finding a perfect title, but now I‚Äôd just leave it as it is, noticing my recovering perfectionist part closing its eyes with horror!

üôà

The part would get absolutely terrified, as it would begin following the note with this article being moved into the folder containing my published website.

/web/heymichal.github.io/_posts

At this point I actually went through the steps I just outlined, which brought the third look at the title of this article, which resulted in a decision to call it:

Personal Website Flow - How I Use This Website

Not perfect, but good enough for now and safe enough to try.

I‚Äôve copy-pasted the front matter from another post (I could have inserted it from template to make it faster), which forced me to add a description and relevant tags.

IMG

And just like that this note is ready to publish.

2

1

üöÄ

It‚Äôs live.

IMG

Please note that it‚Äôs imperfect as fuck.

I mean there is a paragraph typed below that I wrote before and decided not to include, but felt bad to delete it because it feels like a good paragraph to come back to at some point. Moreover, there are no screenshots included, and the links are all missing.

Definitely suboptimal.

But here‚Äôs the most important thing:

I just published a 911 words article in 20 minutes or so. That‚Äôs a second thing I published today.

Hey, I might tweet it, just for the laughs. I feel like it‚Äôs something that [Rob] would appreciate.

As I get ready to copy the link so I can place it into the tweet, I start reading the published article. Perfect - I‚Äôll catch some basic spelling mistakes and small shit like that. I won‚Äôt bother with deep proof reading, images or links.

‚è≥

Proofreading is now complete, which means I can cmd+Tab to GitHub Desktop and commit.

That is all, folks.

Funny enough, I decide not to take this final step right now, because I notice that lonely paragraph again, and on an impulse decide to make it an integral part of this article, rather than leaving a few random lines at the end of the article completely out of context. I guess that‚Äôs fair to you..

To give context, we need to return to the poem.

I was editing it so I can get it ready for a spoken word collaboration with [Jo√£o Moreira] - one of the two Portuguese men whom I connected with deeply many years back in Albania, and on my return to Edinburgh which was my home at the time, I immediately booked my tickets to Portugal to fly there 2 months later. It turned out that I‚Äôd find a Person I would spend 8 years together with, and eventually move to Portugal, where I‚Äôm living now (although it‚Äôs not the continental part of Portugal).

Okay, tangent finished. It‚Äôs still random. Forgive me.

In any case, the poem is still awaiting editing, which is actually perfect, because I feel like my work here is done for now.

I just need two clicks to republish this article, send the link to Rob, and then come back to what I was doing, before a sudden breeze of air would bring me here together with you.

BIRDS SURFING OCEAN WIND VIDEO

I used to be a turtle.

Now I am a bird.

items.content_html:
Gratitude Token is a collaborative game designed to catalyse expressing gratitude within a community.

Overview

Gratitude is a state of the highest vibration. Gratitude Tokens play with the cryptocurrency mechanics, by creating a physical token incentivising expressing gratitude within a community in a playful way.

üÉè Gratitude token has now been carrrdified.

‚òÄÔ∏è This game was prototyped with Bart Hoorweg at the Traditional Dream Factory.

üå± If you‚Äôd like to encourage me to create more games, I invite you to become my Patreon and/or offer a gift.

üê• Twitter thread for the game.

üíú link to our teleram group - GratiDAO

Note: by now I am not really using the Gratitude Ledger as it felt to complicated in practice. It‚Äôs a beautiful piece of the game though, so I‚Äôll keep the instructions in case you want to incorporate it or build upon it.

Prep

  • Prepare tokens by cutting a thick branch into small coins. Make sure there‚Äôs at least one per person, plus a few additional tokens. You can also use carrrds of course.
  • Prepare a few markers and a pen.
  • (optional) Grab a notebook (or a few pieces of paper) and create a Gratitude Token Ledger. Draw the Gratitude Token symbol on the cover page, then write tokenomics instructions on the first available page. You can then ‚Äúmint‚Äù the first token and record the first entry in the ledger (see below).
  • Optional but fun to have: a piece of paper stating: HODL ‚â†¬†GWYC

Gratitude Token Ledger

Below are the instructions (v1) to include in the Ledger. Feel free to modify them to fit your context. You‚Äôll find a few ideas at the end.

Tokenomics

  1. A Gratitude Token is a physical object serving as a catalyst to express gratitude.
  2. Give your Gratitude Token(s) to people you feel grateful for.
  3. Do not HODL your tokens! Instead Give Whenever You Can ‚Äì GWYC (pronounce: QUICK)
  4. If you realise that you are HODLing Gratitude Token(s), take a moment to be grateful for all the gifts in your life and give your token(s) away to someone that deserves it.
  5. If you suspect someone is HODLing Gratitude Tokens, give them a Gratitude Token to model giving behaviour.
  6. Whenever you run out of tokens, you can mint new Gratitude Tokens at any time at your local minting station. To mint, prepare a wooden piece, draw the Gratitude Token Symbol, and add a personal mark. Next, state your Proof of Work by completing an entry in the Gratitude Token Ledger by drawing your personal mark and answer in writing why are you minting this token.

Ledger Records

Here are the records from our Ledger at TDF.

Introducing Gratitude Tokens

Here‚Äôs a suggested format. Tweak as necessary to fit your context.

  1. Gratitude Modeling Check-in: Pass a Gratitude Token (eg. the first one you minted during the prep) as a talking stick. When it‚Äôs your turn to speak, share with the next person what are you grateful for to them. The aim of this round is to bring everyone to the gratitude vibration, as well as model using the token.
  2. Gratitude Token Info: Share about the importance of gratitude and explain why you want to introduce this game in your community. If you have played this game before you can also share a personal story.
  3. Tokenomics: Read out the tokenomics instructions and check for clarity. If you have a ‚ÄúHODL ‚â†¬†GWYC‚Äù sign, then show it while explaining rule 3 - it helps people get the joke.
  4. Minting: Invite everyone to mint a token and record an entry into the ledger. Note that recording in the ledger might take a while.
  5. Next Steps: Invite the group to pass the gratitude tokens. Share the collective challenge of the game: make every token pass through as many hands as possible.
  6. Closing: Close the session with a check-out of your choice.

Notes

  • Tokens don‚Äôt need to stay within a community. Make them travel ‚õµÔ∏èand remember to GWYC.
  • If you receive a gratitude token out of nowhere and/or decide to introduce this game in your community, I‚Äôd love to connect with you.
  • Idea to explore: Gratitude Token Burn Ceremony
  • Idea to explore: Programmable Tokens - use the backside of the token to add extra instructions to the token

Tokenomics Proposals

Have a new proposal? Submit it via our telegram group.

  • When illegal tender (not registered in the ledger) is found, the present members of the gratitude economy will burn the token in an Abundance Ceremony where we express our gratitude for the land, space, community, and all of the surrounding abundance. {source: TDF}
  • New arrivals are welcomed with a gratitude token and encouraged to mint their own when the first grateful moment arises. {source: TDF}
  • When a token has gone full circle (every community member has had it at some point), it can be offered back to nature in an Abundance Ceremony (burning the token). {source: TDF}
  • Whenever you find a TOOP (Token Out Of Place) take a moment to reflect what are you grateful for and claim it as yours. Don‚Äôt HODL! {source: Pico}

items.title: Thirty Three
items.summary: Facing the shadow as I approach another birthda
items.content_text: Out of curiosity I took a look at a numerological meaning behind the number thirty three, and it was certainly an encouraging moment, considering that I‚Äôm about to turn that age in a few days.  ‚ÄúThe 33 embodies both the intuitive, visionary qualities of the 11 and the 22‚Äôs ability to manifest these visions in the material world.‚ÄùKeep going‚Ä¶  ‚ÄúThis blend of a soft heart, inspiring outlook, and the ability to understand and communicate concepts of growth and healing are exactly what makes the number 33 the Master Teacher.‚ÄùNow, I don‚Äôt really care that much if this interpretation applies to my context or not, because I know that I can manifest any reality I choose. And the reality connected with the number thirty three seems definitely like something I‚Äôd like to aim to manifest in the coming years.A little confession:I‚Äôve been having a hard time recently.I guess it‚Äôs the proximity of another birthday that makes me consider existential questions such as what do I have to show for myself and what is my contribution to the world. It makes me think of the Funeral Exercise: what would be the speeches on your funeral like?.I guess there is an egoistic tendency here to ‚Äúbe special‚Äù, ‚Äúmake an impact‚Äù and simply ‚Äúmatter‚Äù, but I find that it‚Äôs also a useful lens to look at ones life, and brutally strip it off from all the mundane bullshit that doesn‚Äôt really matter.Anyway.Truth is, I‚Äôve had quite a difficult time while taking a long hard honest look at myself. I like to think of myself as a ‚Äúgood person‚Äù, whatever that means, and I do have a deep underlying sense that everything is unfolding perfectly, including this trying moment of meticulous self-assessment.In the same time I notice things that feel hard to admit.I feel angry.I feel impatient.I find it easy to start something, but hard to maintain it.I‚Äôm also noticing a big tension around the subject of money. Fuck, that‚Äôs actually a big one. Somehow, I find an expense of ‚Ç¨300 to visit my parents and sister after two and half years a significant hole in my personal budget and I need to carefully juggle my finances to make it happen. WTF.I live cheaply. I don‚Äôt need much. And yet, somehow I can‚Äôt seem to unlock access to the infinite financial abundance that the world has to offer, despite trying for years. It‚Äôs frustrating and it adds up to the feeling of anger. Perhaps the worst part is that I know that it‚Äôs all within myself and I can indeed shift it at any point. I just never managed to do it.Now, I‚Äôm not complaining by any means, and I do feel immensely grateful for what I have.In fact, I‚Äôve been gifted a beautiful lifestyle in an idyllic place, surrounded by people who I get to call my Island Family. That definitely counts for A LOT and it‚Äôs more than many people could ever wish for. It seems worth much more than a few zeros of net worth. And yet, a part of me can‚Äôt relax.So I lay down on the floor of my 3x3 wooden cabin in a beautiful forest with an ocean view, the most amazing house I‚Äôve ever lived in, and sink down into myself.Why am I feeling agitated? What is it inside of me that is not in alignment? Why am I feeling so disconnected in the last few weeks?My cat-mate Kiki sleeps on my chest. I can feel her weight as I inhale and exhale. The binaural beats relax me. I let go of the tension and accept myself with all the perceived imperfections. I notice them in a different light, too.My vices are inseparably interwoven with my virtues and vice versa.The anger is an imbalance of inextinguishable life force, allowing me to not be afraid to make difficult choices and stick with them.The impatience derives from wanting to manifest dreams.The difficulty to maintain connects with seeing potential in everything, which fuels my tendency to naturally help people with whatever struggle they go through.What a convoluted mess of self.There‚Äôs more, but I won‚Äôt elaborate further.The bottom line is that as my birthday approaches it‚Äôs time to make some tough decisions. I can‚Äôt do everything. I don‚Äôt want to do everything. I don‚Äôt always know what I want, or to be more precise - I intuitively feel what is my path, but sometimes I disconnect from myself by staying way too much in my head.I notice that my mind is precisely where the money messes me up.The second I consider questions like ‚Äúhow does this idea bring money‚Äù or ‚Äúhow do I support myself financially‚Äù, I close, disconnect and get stuck again. Out of curiosity I took a look at a numerological meaning behind the number thirty three, and it was certainly an encouraging moment, considering that I‚Äôm about to turn that age in a few days.

‚ÄúThe 33 embodies both the intuitive, visionary qualities of the 11 and the 22‚Äôs ability to manifest these visions in the material world.‚Äù

Keep going‚Ä¶

‚ÄúThis blend of a soft heart, inspiring outlook, and the ability to understand and communicate concepts of growth and healing are exactly what makes the number 33 the Master Teacher.‚Äù

Now, I don‚Äôt really care that much if this interpretation applies to my context or not, because I know that I can manifest any reality I choose. And the reality connected with the number thirty three seems definitely like something I‚Äôd like to aim to manifest in the coming years.

A little confession:

I‚Äôve been having a hard time recently.

I guess it‚Äôs the proximity of another birthday that makes me consider existential questions such as what do I have to show for myself and what is my contribution to the world. It makes me think of the Funeral Exercise: what would be the speeches on your funeral like?.

I guess there is an egoistic tendency here to ‚Äúbe special‚Äù, ‚Äúmake an impact‚Äù and simply ‚Äúmatter‚Äù, but I find that it‚Äôs also a useful lens to look at ones life, and brutally strip it off from all the mundane bullshit that doesn‚Äôt really matter.

Anyway.

Truth is, I‚Äôve had quite a difficult time while taking a long hard honest look at myself. I like to think of myself as a ‚Äúgood person‚Äù, whatever that means, and I do have a deep underlying sense that everything is unfolding perfectly, including this trying moment of meticulous self-assessment.

In the same time I notice things that feel hard to admit.

I feel angry.

I feel impatient.

I find it easy to start something, but hard to maintain it.

I‚Äôm also noticing a big tension around the subject of money. Fuck, that‚Äôs actually a big one. Somehow, I find an expense of ‚Ç¨300 to visit my parents and sister after two and half years a significant hole in my personal budget and I need to carefully juggle my finances to make it happen. WTF.

I live cheaply. I don‚Äôt need much. And yet, somehow I can‚Äôt seem to unlock access to the infinite financial abundance that the world has to offer, despite trying for years. It‚Äôs frustrating and it adds up to the feeling of anger. Perhaps the worst part is that I know that it‚Äôs all within myself and I can indeed shift it at any point. I just never managed to do it.

Now, I‚Äôm not complaining by any means, and I do feel immensely grateful for what I have.

In fact, I‚Äôve been gifted a beautiful lifestyle in an idyllic place, surrounded by people who I get to call my Island Family. That definitely counts for A LOT and it‚Äôs more than many people could ever wish for. It seems worth much more than a few zeros of net worth. And yet, a part of me can‚Äôt relax.

So I lay down on the floor of my 3x3 wooden cabin in a beautiful forest with an ocean view, the most amazing house I‚Äôve ever lived in, and sink down into myself.

Why am I feeling agitated? What is it inside of me that is not in alignment? Why am I feeling so disconnected in the last few weeks?

My cat-mate Kiki sleeps on my chest. I can feel her weight as I inhale and exhale. The binaural beats relax me. I let go of the tension and accept myself with all the perceived imperfections. I notice them in a different light, too.

My vices are inseparably interwoven with my virtues and vice versa.

The anger is an imbalance of inextinguishable life force, allowing me to not be afraid to make difficult choices and stick with them.

The impatience derives from wanting to manifest dreams.

The difficulty to maintain connects with seeing potential in everything, which fuels my tendency to naturally help people with whatever struggle they go through.

What a convoluted mess of self.

There‚Äôs more, but I won‚Äôt elaborate further.

The bottom line is that as my birthday approaches it‚Äôs time to make some tough decisions. I can‚Äôt do everything. I don‚Äôt want to do everything. I don‚Äôt always know what I want, or to be more precise - I intuitively feel what is my path, but sometimes I disconnect from myself by staying way too much in my head.

I notice that my mind is precisely where the money messes me up.

The second I consider questions like ‚Äúhow does this idea bring money‚Äù or ‚Äúhow do I support myself financially‚Äù, I close, disconnect and get stuck again. My mind starts spinning, and combined with the tendency to overthink, it happily goes forever, bringing me overwhelm, with enough glimpse of possibility to keep luring me deeper into this trap.

Argh.

How to leave it behind?

I wish I‚Äôd know.

The thing is, I do know, I just don‚Äôt have access to it. Not yet.

Or‚Ä¶?

As I dance underneath the starlit sky above the deck of my cabin, I shake off the doubts and bring in new energy.

A new cycle of my life is afoot.

It‚Äôs up to me to make it whatever I want it to be.

And I do.

items.content_text: The first New Moon of 2022 is a perfect time to share with you my Yearly Review.It‚Äôs been a very special year in my life ‚Äì¬†it marked the beginning of a New Cycle, which I wish to be all about manifesting dreams. I feel like everything that happened this year was a long process of integrating everything that happened in my life so far, and preparing me for something new.Here‚Äôs the drawing of my year:I‚Äôll share with you a bit more about it, using a few scans from the pages of my 2021 journals, captured during my yearly review.Enjoy üíúYear of SquaresThe year begins with the Squares of course.You‚Äôll notice that they changed quite significantly through the year. This is the page that took me from 15 Nov 2020 to 12 Jan 2021.Squares were a major theme of the year. I finally figured out what they are really about, and what is the most effective and fun way for me to inspire others to play along. In September I finally transformed the unpronounceable Minimalist Journaling System into Infinity Squares, and launched a brand new email-based course.As you can see below, my squares evolved a lot. Here‚Äôs September 2021:And in case you‚Äôre wondering, I still haven‚Äôt skipped a single one in over 1400 days. It is the most fundamental self-alignment practice in my life.On the other hand, I also realised that I need to make space in my professional life. I‚Äôve been feeling a lot of confusion around JournalSmarter, which led to writing a letter to it (as in to the brand itself), where I tried to inquire what does JS want to become. After a long and painful process, I‚Äôve decided to radically simplify my entire approach and launched (today) a new website. JournalSmarter will no longer be my main professional focus, in order to make space for what I feel called to do (more on that later). I‚Äôll still keep the courses going and add a new journaling game / course whenever I feel like it. I also have a few pieces of the journaling puzzle that are ready to be published, so I‚Äôll make than happen in the next few days. And then it‚Äôs time to breathe.Paradoxically, by removing all the financial pressure from JournalSmarter, as well as radically simplifying how it works, I have a feeling that this project will be more successful than ever. And I admit that the moment of insight which lead me to describe journaling as an infinite game unlocked something that has been stuck for a long time.Welcome to JournalSmarter 3.0. I hope that it will bring you a lot of joy.üìñ‚ú®Year of PracticeIn December 2019 I had this crazy idea to offer a year-long cohort-based course, where I‚Äôll take 20 people on a journey of building 3 practices of their choice through the year.I‚Äôm still due to write an in-depth documentation article on that journey, so I won‚Äôt go into more details now, and instead I‚Äôll share about my own practices. Funny enough, they were completely different from what I expected them to be.BeingIn the summer I felt a call to ditch the comforts of a house and moved into a forest. It has been the most impactful summer of my life, along with 2013 (when I hitchhiked from Scotland to Greece) and 2017 (when I said goodbye to Edinburgh and began location independent life).Photo by Austƒója Liup≈°eviƒçi≈´tƒóBeing in the forest started a deep process of reconnection with myself, tuning into my intuition, which allowed me to rediscover what is important to me and how I want to manifest it. I am forever grateful to Jean-Daniel who allowed me to live on his land, as well as Austeja and Niko, who were my forest neighbours.My home in the Magical ForestI started to write poetry and letters again, I felt free like I haven‚Äôt in a couple of years, and I have learnt a few critical lessons, which I then integrated on a trip to the Mainland Portugal in September, which blew my mind beyond anything I knew before.WalkingThe seed of walking has been planted during my little camino in Faial island. I felt called to go there and connect with the island, and instead of cycling or driving I wanted to walk. So I walked for three days pretty much non-stop, covering the entire island, climbing up and down volcanoes, and sleeping in a hammock in the forest.In September, I spent three weeks walking in Lisbon and Porto, for most of my waking hours. Soon after walking up I‚Äôd leave the house and began walking, walking, walking only to come back late at night to sleep and then walk again the following day.I have never reached such a deep level of self-awareness until that trip. I‚Äôve experienced unprecedented abundance, flow of synchronicities, moments of beauty, unexpected beautiful connections with people and other beings, and powerful insights. It changed me.I don‚Äôt really have words to describe it just yet.I wrote ‚ÄúI want to‚Äù and then decided to strike it through, as ‚ÄúI am‚Äù walking and writing stories. It is happening already. And if you‚Äôre curious about what was the story written below, it is here and it was a moment of vulnerable and hilarious insight.In 2021, walking became my meditation. My way of Being. items.content_html:
The first New Moon of 2022 is a perfect time to share with you my Yearly Review.

It‚Äôs been a very special year in my life ‚Äì¬†it marked the beginning of a New Cycle, which I wish to be all about manifesting dreams. I feel like everything that happened this year was a long process of integrating everything that happened in my life so far, and preparing me for something new.

Here‚Äôs the drawing of my year:

I‚Äôll share with you a bit more about it, using a few scans from the pages of my 2021 journals, captured during my yearly review.

Enjoy üíú

Year of Squares

The year begins with the Squares of course.

You‚Äôll notice that they changed quite significantly through the year. This is the page that took me from 15 Nov 2020 to 12 Jan 2021.

Squares were a major theme of the year. I finally figured out what they are really about, and what is the most effective and fun way for me to inspire others to play along. In September I finally transformed the unpronounceable Minimalist Journaling System into Infinity Squares, and launched a brand new email-based course.

As you can see below, my squares evolved a lot. Here‚Äôs September 2021:

And in case you‚Äôre wondering, I still haven‚Äôt skipped a single one in over 1400 days. It is the most fundamental self-alignment practice in my life.

On the other hand, I also realised that I need to make space in my professional life. I‚Äôve been feeling a lot of confusion around JournalSmarter, which led to writing a letter to it (as in to the brand itself), where I tried to inquire what does JS want to become. After a long and painful process, I‚Äôve decided to radically simplify my entire approach and launched (today) a new website. JournalSmarter will no longer be my main professional focus, in order to make space for what I feel called to do (more on that later). I‚Äôll still keep the courses going and add a new journaling game / course whenever I feel like it. I also have a few pieces of the journaling puzzle that are ready to be published, so I‚Äôll make than happen in the next few days. And then it‚Äôs time to breathe.

Paradoxically, by removing all the financial pressure from JournalSmarter, as well as radically simplifying how it works, I have a feeling that this project will be more successful than ever. And I admit that the moment of insight which lead me to describe journaling as an infinite game unlocked something that has been stuck for a long time.

Welcome to JournalSmarter 3.0. I hope that it will bring you a lot of joy.

üìñ‚ú®

Year of Practice

In December 2019 I had this crazy idea to offer a year-long cohort-based course, where I‚Äôll take 20 people on a journey of building 3 practices of their choice through the year.

I‚Äôm still due to write an in-depth documentation article on that journey, so I won‚Äôt go into more details now, and instead I‚Äôll share about my own practices. Funny enough, they were completely different from what I expected them to be.

Being

In the summer I felt a call to ditch the comforts of a house and moved into a forest. It has been the most impactful summer of my life, along with 2013 (when I hitchhiked from Scotland to Greece) and 2017 (when I said goodbye to Edinburgh and began location independent life).

Photo by Austƒója Liup≈°eviƒçi≈´tƒó

Being in the forest started a deep process of reconnection with myself, tuning into my intuition, which allowed me to rediscover what is important to me and how I want to manifest it. I am forever grateful to Jean-Daniel who allowed me to live on his land, as well as Austeja and Niko, who were my forest neighbours.

My home in the Magical Forest

I started to write poetry and letters again, I felt free like I haven‚Äôt in a couple of years, and I have learnt a few critical lessons, which I then integrated on a trip to the Mainland Portugal in September, which blew my mind beyond anything I knew before.

Walking

The seed of walking has been planted during my little camino in Faial island. I felt called to go there and connect with the island, and instead of cycling or driving I wanted to walk. So I walked for three days pretty much non-stop, covering the entire island, climbing up and down volcanoes, and sleeping in a hammock in the forest.

In September, I spent three weeks walking in Lisbon and Porto, for most of my waking hours. Soon after walking up I‚Äôd leave the house and began walking, walking, walking only to come back late at night to sleep and then walk again the following day.

I have never reached such a deep level of self-awareness until that trip. I‚Äôve experienced unprecedented abundance, flow of synchronicities, moments of beauty, unexpected beautiful connections with people and other beings, and powerful insights. It changed me.

I don‚Äôt really have words to describe it just yet.

I wrote ‚ÄúI want to‚Äù and then decided to strike it through, as ‚ÄúI am‚Äù walking and writing stories. It is happening already. And if you‚Äôre curious about what was the story written below, it is here and it was a moment of vulnerable and hilarious insight.

In 2021, walking became my meditation. My way of Being. My lifestyle.

It‚Äôs all I need in order to encounter and create Magic. And Magic is precisely what I‚Äôm after.

Making Space

Creating spaces for magic to emerge is something that I feel called for, and it‚Äôs also when I feel like fish in the sea.

This year was special in that regard.

I co-hosted the first community gathering in Pico, which was a game-changer for the community. Before the gathering I used to feel that I have friends in the island. After the gathering I had a family.

I took this energy further with our second gathering, designed to 1) help each of us to understand what kind of community do we want to be a part of, and 2) find ways to support each other to make these visions come true in the context of our island. It was a very special moment for our community and for me, as a catalyst. Here‚Äôs a community catalysing game I prototyped during the gathering.

I still remember the crazy brainstorming session when the game idea came to me:

My wonderful island family gave life to the prototype and created a map full of exciting projects.

I‚Äôve also created a performance with Austeja, which moved local people and kids in ways that we haven‚Äôt expected. We also co-created a more events in Pico, such as Slam Jam, Masking Around, and more. We also had our bi-weekly sharing circle and a drum crew. Loads and Loads of spaces and even more magical moments that emerged from there.

I‚Äôve also had the honour to create a wedding ceremony for a dear friend and his lovely partner. I loved it and I‚Äôm game for creating more ceremonies. Call me üòâ.

Apart from making spaces in real life, I‚Äôve also created some powerful digital experiences, such as Year of Practice (a year-long practice-building community), Habit Sprint (a three-month, focused version), Relational Weekly Review (a weekly co-journaling session boosted with relational growth), *Enspiral Europe Connection Weekend (an experiment in weaving social fabric in the European part of Enspiral network) and more.

Intermission: Top Songs, Films, and Books of 2021.

Three Songs That Moved Me

Adult Jazz - Springful
bandcamp | spotify

As I was about to depart for a trip that would turn out to be the most powerful journey in my life so far, I asked my best friend for a gift: a few songs to go along with me. Springful was the one that created a powerful emotional shift inside of me, and prompted me to dance, dance, dance and then dance some more, as I was deepening my self-awareness reaching unprecedented levels, while walking for hours in the streets of Lisbon and Porto.

It is one of these few songs that will always stay with me, reminding me of this very special moment in my personal history whenever I get to listen to it.

Milo - Folk Metaphysics
soundcloud | spotify
lyrics

I remember the moment when this song came into my headphones for the first time. I paused. I listen to it, and then listened to it on repeat a few times to really understand the lyrics. There‚Äôs something about this song that puts me in a very special state of Being ‚Äì¬†humble, honest, creative, melancholic, connected.

Milo is one of the most important poets I discovered this year, and I highly recommend his work.

Climbing Poetree - Awakening
bancamp| spotify
lyrics

Speaking of poets, here‚Äôs two of them, united in a raw and powerful force of nature poetry. Listening to this song (and a few other ones) make me shiver, and there are not many songs that can do that.

Note:I deliberately avoided youtube links for the songs, as I‚Äôm on a quest to set myself free from google. It‚Äôs not an easy task and it requires practice.

Three Films that I absolutely loved

The Twentieth Century
Mubi

Incredible example of neo-German-expressionism, depicting the story of a Canadian prime minister rising to power. The vibe is really quite something, and it‚Äôs good old-school set design, not computer generated stuff.

The Brick
Wikipedia

Dear, oh dear, what a feast.

The dialogue, the characters, the intrigue, the cinematography‚Ä¶ I loved all of it. And translating the tropes of noir into American high-school environment works exceptionally well. Make no mistake ‚Äì this is nothing like a typical American high-school comedy. Brick is a piece of art.

One of my favourite moments is the conversation when the hero rejects help from la famme:

BRENDAN
Look, I can‚Äôt trust you. You ought to be smart enough to know that. I didn‚Äôt shake up the party to get your attention, and I‚Äôm not heeling you to hook you. Your connections could help me, but the bad baggage they bring could make it zero sum game or even hurt me. Better off coming at it clean.

LAURA
I wouldn‚Äôt have to lead you in by the‚Ä¶

BRENDAN
I can‚Äôt trust you. Brad was a sap, you weren‚Äôt. You‚Äôre with him, so you‚Äôre playing him. So you‚Äôre a player. With you behind me, I‚Äôd have to tie one eye up, watching both of your hands. I can‚Äôt spare it.

You‚Äôre absolutely right, Brendan. She is a player indeed.

Another Round
Mubi

Four school teachers embark on an experiment to prove an obscure theory: maintain a constant level of alcohol to see if it will make them happy. The result is a wonderfully dark comedy from the magnificent Scandinavian school of film-making.

Speaking of good films, I can‚Äôt recommend MUBI enough. The curation is amazing, and instead of force-feeding whatever into your throat like Netflix, Mubi actually helps you find cinematic gems. This link gets you (and me) a free month.

Honorable mention: A Gathering of the Tribe

A powerful, 9 minute short, perfectly fitting for our current times. It really touched me.

Youtube link

Book of the Year

Sacred Economics by Charles Eisenstein. No doubt here.

In fact, I find Charles to be one of the most important writers of today‚Äôs world. I can‚Äôt recommend checking out his work on Substack. Here‚Äôs one of the recent essays that expressed very accurately a lot of my feelings regarding that virus: A Path Will Rise to Meet Us.

The Alternative Culture is here. All we need to do is shine ‚ú®

Most of all, the 2021 shown me that the (for a lack of better word) global capitalist culture is not only complete bullshit (this I knew for a long time), but the alternative is already here and so many people already made the shift. It‚Äôs possible. It‚Äôs happening. No more excuses and keeping the hamster wheel going.

It‚Äôs been such a privilege to learn from and with all the wonderful souls I‚Äôve met this year. Here are a few of them along with ideas they shared with me:

It‚Äôs not that the change is coming.

It is right here, right now.

All we need to do is shine ‚ú®.

And, of course, NO FEAR.

Fear is the heart killer.

Gratitude Mandala

Speaking of the people I‚Äôve been lucky to connect with‚Ä¶

Every year I draw a Gratitude Mandala, which includes beings I‚Äôm grateful for in the year that has ended. It‚Äôs a part of my yearly review since 2019.

Here‚Äôs my mandala for 2021:

Since I‚Äôve been reconnecting with my letter writing practice recently, I‚Äôve decided to write as many letters to as many of these wonderful souls as possible. Some of the letters will be public, and I‚Äôll keep adding them here.

For now, there‚Äôs only a letter to Kiki, the wonderful cat that lives with me, which is an absolutely amazing being, and I‚Äôve learn a lot from her.

And hey, since you are here right now:

THANK YOU FOR BEING A PART OF MY LIFE.

üíú üíú üíú

Setting a new course for 2022

New Lunar Year is a good moment to adjust the course I‚Äôm taking in life.

I still feel like doing a bit more internal soul-searching in that field, but the direction is clear.

My #1 priority in 2022 is to create and document regenerative communities.

It seems like it‚Äôs a perfect Ikigai ‚Äì a direction encompassing something the world needs, something I‚Äôm good at, something I love doing and something I can get paid for. I wrote a sweet article about Ikigai a long time ago, and I actually feel like revisiting the exercises I shared there.

But for now, here‚Äôs a hypothesis:

If I make more space for my community catalysing activities and keep documenting what I do and how I do it (whether in Pico, the Azores, Enspiral or in digital spaces) my work will create a serious ripple effect inspiring and encouraging people to create their own communities and regenerative projects. And part of that ripple effect will come back to me in the form of gratitude and financial support allowing me to do more meaningful work in that area.

In other words, instead of pushing to sell products, I‚Äôd rather be supported by people who believe that what I do is important, and who want to help me make it happen. So, I‚Äôve set up a Patreon account and I‚Äôm curious to see if it‚Äôs a viable path for me right now. It‚Äôd mean the world to me if you would consider being a part of that journey.

You can see what I‚Äôm focusing on here.

I wish you Freedom, Joy and Fulfilment. Let‚Äôs co-create a beautiful world where all beings can thrive. It‚Äôs possible. All we need to do is shine ‚ú®.

Thank you for Being,
Micha≈Ç

items.content_text: Note: I failed this experiment. It‚Äôs 2023 and I‚Äôm still using Google. üôÅ2022 is the time to finally ditch Google from my personal and professional life, as much as possible.Why? Because:  I don‚Äôt align with its values  I‚Äôm disturbed by the insane power that a single corporation has  There are plenty of functional and awesome alternatives  I‚Äôm done sacrificing my values for convenienceIn other words: I can‚Äôt bullshit myself anymore that it‚Äôs too hard. It just takes some time.If you need more convincing on why ditch Google, there are some resources at the end of this post.Wanna chat about this? Tweet me.Using Google is a habitAs I embarked on this journey, I noticed that quitting google is very similar to quitting a bad habit. Over numerous year of interacting with the internet, I have conditioned myself to default to google, and it‚Äôs not easy at all to give it up.This is a powerful realisation, because I am a certified habit building coach, and I have worked with clients (and myself) in the area of habit building for quite some time. This means I know exactly how to approach this situation effectively, or at least give it my best shot.The critical idea in habit-building is to steadily keep moving forward with a tiny habit, rather than overcommitting. This is why I don‚Äôt intend to migrate away from google in a week or so, but rather see it as an ongoing process, which I‚Äôm going to document here.Here‚Äôs my (ongoing) process:‚úÖGoogle ChromeI always preferred Firefox. Brave is cool too (I use it on mobile). Easy peasy.Google SearchMojeek + DuckDuckGoI swapped to DuckDuckGo years ago and it used to be my default search engine until I read this amazing article exploring private search engines. Turns out DDG stores some information, plus it is US-based, which doesn‚Äôt inspire my confidence at all.I‚Äôve decided to move to Mojeek as my primary search, and supplement it with DDG whenever necessary.Youtube for musicSpotifyI‚Äôve quit youtube for music when I joined Spotify. I have a family premium account. Other alternatives I like are Soundcloud and Bandcamp . The latter is a great way of supporting artists I love financially and downloading music for offline use, which will come in handy when I move to a sailboat ‚õµÔ∏è.‚è≥Google DriveCryptdriveI love cryptdrive and it was a no-brainer to switch. I‚Äôm using it for all new files, but I still need to migrate documents from Google Drive.Unfortunately, this is one of these things that have a tendency of sending me down a rabbit hole of over organising folders etc. I admit my drive is a combination of well organised PARA system and a folder with all the mess that I made over the years, which I never got to really clean up.It‚Äôs worth noting here that I‚Äôm redesigning my computer experience for offline-first and obsidian-centered.GmailProtonmailAfter going on a rabbit hole of research triggered by this article  about secure emails, I reached a conclusion that there is no fully private option on the market. Even Protonmail and Tutanota have serious issues.After considering different pros and cons, I made my decision to go with protonmail. Note: I failed this experiment. It‚Äôs 2023 and I‚Äôm still using Google. üôÅ

2022 is the time to finally ditch Google from my personal and professional life, as much as possible.

Why? Because:

  • I don‚Äôt align with its values
  • I‚Äôm disturbed by the insane power that a single corporation has
  • There are plenty of functional and awesome alternatives
  • I‚Äôm done sacrificing my values for convenience

In other words: I can‚Äôt bullshit myself anymore that it‚Äôs too hard. It just takes some time.

If you need more convincing on why ditch Google, there are some resources at the end of this post.

Wanna chat about this? Tweet me.

Using Google is a habit

As I embarked on this journey, I noticed that quitting google is very similar to quitting a bad habit. Over numerous year of interacting with the internet, I have conditioned myself to default to google, and it‚Äôs not easy at all to give it up.

This is a powerful realisation, because I am a certified habit building coach, and I have worked with clients (and myself) in the area of habit building for quite some time. This means I know exactly how to approach this situation effectively, or at least give it my best shot.

The critical idea in habit-building is to steadily keep moving forward with a tiny habit, rather than overcommitting. This is why I don‚Äôt intend to migrate away from google in a week or so, but rather see it as an ongoing process, which I‚Äôm going to document here.

Here‚Äôs my (ongoing) process:

‚úÖ


Google Chrome

I always preferred Firefox. Brave is cool too (I use it on mobile). Easy peasy.

Google Search

Mojeek + DuckDuckGo

I swapped to DuckDuckGo years ago and it used to be my default search engine until I read this amazing article exploring private search engines. Turns out DDG stores some information, plus it is US-based, which doesn‚Äôt inspire my confidence at all.

I‚Äôve decided to move to Mojeek as my primary search, and supplement it with DDG whenever necessary.

Youtube for music

Spotify

I‚Äôve quit youtube for music when I joined Spotify. I have a family premium account. Other alternatives I like are Soundcloud and Bandcamp . The latter is a great way of supporting artists I love financially and downloading music for offline use, which will come in handy when I move to a sailboat ‚õµÔ∏è.

‚è≥


Google Drive

Cryptdrive

I love cryptdrive and it was a no-brainer to switch. I‚Äôm using it for all new files, but I still need to migrate documents from Google Drive.

Unfortunately, this is one of these things that have a tendency of sending me down a rabbit hole of over organising folders etc. I admit my drive is a combination of well organised PARA system and a folder with all the mess that I made over the years, which I never got to really clean up.

It‚Äôs worth noting here that I‚Äôm redesigning my computer experience for offline-first and obsidian-centered.

Gmail

Protonmail

After going on a rabbit hole of research triggered by this article about secure emails, I reached a conclusion that there is no fully private option on the market. Even Protonmail and Tutanota have serious issues.

After considering different pros and cons, I made my decision to go with protonmail. It‚Äôs not perfect, but definitely better than gmail.

Unfortunately, this is where the migration becomes tricky.

1) All my digital world relies on multiple @gmail addresses and the process of moving to Proton is essentially an opportunity to practice one of the virtues I‚Äôm not so good at ‚Äì patience.

2) My recovering-perfectionist mind wants me to create a perfect combination of email addresses, for personal, work and secret purposes.

The habit-building work begins here. I created my free protonmail account and started using it for creating new accounts, subscriptions etc. I‚Äôll eventually move to a paid plan, as I ditch my business google accounts.

Google Calendar

Proton Calendar

There are three problems with Proton Calendar:

  • the design on mobile is quite poor for my use case, and since I have to use the dedicated app I can‚Äôt fix it with a third-party app
  • development cycles in Proton are ridiculously long.
  • can it work with calendly or other scheduling tool?

For now I started migrating some of my events there, and I‚Äôll continue the process over time.

I just caught myself automatically going to youtube to look for something (LYT obsidian videos), which yet again brings me back to the idea that quitting Google is like quitting a bad habit.

I noticed though, so I went on to try alternatives. Dtube gave me nothing, but Odysee shown more promising results.

This letter is the first I wrote, on my Gratitude Mandala journey ‚Äì expressing gratitude to all beings that I feel grateful for in my year.

üêà


30 December 2021

Dear Kiki,

I‚Äôm writing this letter to you, while you chill on my back. It‚Äôs noticeably colder today and I‚Äôm grateful that you are so committed to being as close as possible to me, whenever I‚Äôm sitting or lying down, like I am right now.

I‚Äôm doing this thing of writing letters to people that I feel very grateful for in 2021, and as I‚Äôve been reflecting on that list, I‚Äôve noticed that you are missing. You are not a person, but it‚Äôs obvious to me that I should rename my list to ‚ÄúBeings I‚Äôm grateful for‚Äù. And you are certainly one of them.

I absolutely love our co-living arrangement. It‚Äôs wonderful to feel your presence and play around with you. You brought me so much laughter when you were climbing the ladder, chilling with your body rolled into a pretzel, or simply being. You are activating a part of me that I love seeing more and more - playful, present, connected with myself and agile. I feel like you have a lot to teach me, and I‚Äôm grateful that you choose to live with me. Ultimately you are free, and that makes me happy. I guess this is obvious to you, but in the human world we‚Äôre conditioned to say nonsense like ‚Äúmy cat‚Äù. For some reason we claim ownership on another being, which I find, frankly speaking, ridiculous.

You are your own being, and you are free to be here with me, or, if you choose, go somewhere else. I‚Äôd of course miss your presence, but I‚Äôd be okay. In the meantime, I‚Äôm happy to provide shelter, company, and food, and all the space you need to explore and live. I admit that I‚Äôd love to experience a day as your shadow once, to see what you are doing when you‚Äôre in the forest. Who knows, maybe one day I‚Äôll have a chance. In fact, it seems like a perfect adventure to embark on: to be a cat‚Äôs shadow. I‚Äôm sure I‚Äôd learn a lot.

For now though, I‚Äôd just like to tell you one more time that I‚Äôm super grateful to have met you and watch your growth from a little cub who came on my lap immediately, to this wonderful healthy young adult that you now are.

I wish you all that is most beautiful for you in the coming year, although I have limited understanding of what it might be.

Thank you for Being,
Micha≈Ç

ps. I‚Äôm also grateful for the name I channeled for you. It really does suit you, you little cheeksto.
